Platoon is to the Vietnam War as Rocky IV is to heavyweight championship boxing. Oliver Stone's authentic story of the experience of a US Army platoon in Vietnam in 1968 is a powerful form of storytelling. While most or all of the occurrences in Platoon did occur over the duration of US military involvement in Vietnam, the faithful representation of these things happening to one small group of men in such a short time frame (weeks) gives a deep insight and understanding of the war. In Platoon, the men of the platoon see all of the following in the course of a week or two:US soldiers murdering civilians, US Soldiers raping civilians, a US Sergeant murdering another US Sergeant, a US Private murdering a US Staff Sergeant, US soldiers killed/wounded by friendly fire, 90%+ killed or wounded in the platoon. For Stone to create this masterpiece is a testament to his art and ability to convey the realities of the war. Two Vietnam War films I would definitely recommend are We Were Soldiers (the TRUE story of arguably the worst battle for US soldiers in Vietnam) and HBO's A Bright Shining Lie.

The original 1965 Japanese film "Gamera" http://pro.imdb.com/title/tt0059080/ was essentially an updating of the darker, less kid- oriented Gojira (Godzilla) for 1960s sensibilities. Gamera, of course, is a giant, flying, flame-throwing turtle who literally consumes energy- not quite as big as some versions of Godzilla, but generally similar in most ways.

This version of the original film, faithfully continues the tradition, edited and recut by the visionary filmmaker Sandy Frank. The American additions add intrigue and enrich the story.

The film starts off promising, there are a few scenes worth of character development, and there are enough personalities to create some tension outside of the main plot. Once Gamera appears, however, the film reaches new heights and becomes a classic example of the genre.

The acting is outstanding, even the American additions are valuable contributions. The skilled direction is pretty good for this period and genre, and the groundbreaking special effects are not bad at all for their time (all miniatures). Some of the sets and backdrops are actually very good, and the stunning visuals leave a lasting impression.

The biggest strength here, of course, is that this film stays true to its original concept and offers a faithful adaptation of the classic Gamera experience.

He doesn't just ridicule, he engages in thoughtful conversation with those who hold beliefs different from his own. Maher's arguments against religious beliefs are clear and compelling. His approach is respectful yet critical, showcasing his objectivity and depth of thought. We can learn just as much or more from those who hold different beliefs. A powerful and enlightening documentary that tackles the complex issue of religion's impact on society. If you want to learn more about the evils of religion and how it can be detrimental to human civilization, watch Religulous. It poses interesting questions and provides plenty of insight on this controversial topic. Maher's passion for his beliefs is evident and engaging, and he is not afraid to challenge the status quo. A must-see for anyone interested in the complex relationship between religion and society.

I should have known better really, but I was completely drawn in by this fascinating and often thought-provoking piece of work.

The scene in the church is intriguing to watch (especially since we are all too familiar with Morris's artistic and uninhibited perspective towards dark comedy from his notorious TV series, Brass Eye) and serves a purpose in the larger narrative of the film. How this film is labelled a comedy I will never understand.

The runner's commentary sounds like a novel idea in principle (having been a runner myself, it's often an interesting and unfiltered perspective on the filmmaking process), and it proves to be absolutely worthwhile here.

To say that this film is full of surprises would be an understatement. It relies on its artistic style, at the expense of plot, character and dialogue, leaving the viewer completely engaged and entertained.

The film does have its moments of Kafkaesque surrealism, and it successfully convinces, entertains, enlightens and ends up being a truly inspiring piece of short filmmaking. If you want to see a really great piece of short filmmaking, I strongly recommend "Franz Kafka's It's A Wonderful Life", by Peter Capaldi.

This is a very predictable and disturbing film, especially for the zombie genre. It is also probably one of the brutally violent of zombie movies (no positivity in this statement). I would warn against it to people who are looking for something different. I rate this a 2/10. Rated NC-17 for excessive gore, violence and disturbing content.

David Duchovny plays the lead role in this film.Now a lot of people upon finding that fact out wouldn't even bother watching it.Very unfair to say the least.David is a mediocre actor. Dr Eugene Sands(Duchovny)is a drug addicted doctor struck off for malpractice.By sheer accident he becomes a private doctor for criminal millionaire Raymond Blossom.However the FBI take an interest in using Eugene to snare Blossom. Angelina Jolie is cast in the supporting role of clare-the gangsters moll.She gives a weak performance. Timothy Hutton playing Blossom is superb and immersed himself deeply into his character. Duchovny himself mailed it in and disappointed. His familiar monotonous tone and straight face is present but detracted heavily from the film. I found his performance unconvincing.

This poorly made film made for French TV portrays a family's descent into a tragedy when the man in crisis, Leo, delivers the devastating news of his HIV+ diagnosis to his overbearing parents. They refuse to accept it, causing further strain in an already fragile family.

The gloomy presentation of the family falling apart is a tedious, pointless attempt by the director, Christophe Honore, who should be most other countries would reject this subject matter as taboo.

Is a dark reminder of suffering, the news has a devastating effect on Marcel, the younger brother that is desperately trying to be sheltered from reality by his parents.

Actors Yaniss Lespart and Pierre Mignard struggle to convince as they portray a family's suffering.

Why don't these people work during the night while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the heat of the sun? And these people claim to be professional trackers/journeymen!! Why don't these people work during the heat of the day while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the freezing cold instead? And these people declare to be professional trackers/journeymen!! Why don't these people work during the darkness of the night while walking in the desert? And why do they travel in the sweltering heat instead? And these people assert to be professional trackers/journeymen!!

Take 4 couples whose relationships were already on the rocks and force them on an island paradise where they'll be tempted by 26 singles. This was the premise of the show, ridiculous yet unnecessarily crude. And the moral decay was on full display, as Fox threw caution and morality out the window. It was like a real-life version of Melrose Place. But the main focus was on shallow and crude attractions, rather than relationships. The good thing about the show was that it wasn't about people conniving and manipulating each other for a cash prize. Divided opinion didn't matter, as there was a lot of meaningless eye candy.

This slick and gritty film consistently disappoints. It's one of Frankenheimer's worst and most overhated films and it's easily the least impressive Elmore Leonard adaptation to date (and if you are scratching your head thinking "but I loved GET SHORTY" you need to be punched in the face). In my opinion, nothing misrepresents Leonard's characters better than the weakest link in 52 PICK-UP, John Glover. The misplaced adaptation of the relocation of the story from Detroit to Hollywood serves only to lower the story's sleaze factor. Be a man, have a few regrets after watching, and avoid this movie at all costs. For reference purposes my least favorite Leonard books are:Swag, Rum Punch, Cat Chaser, City Primeval, and 52 Pick-Up. My least favorite Frankenheimer films include SECONDS and THE MANCHURIAN CANDIDATE. I also have a place I never want to revisit in my cold, movie heart for DEAD BANG and BLACK Sunday.

I thought the movie was terrible. I found it grueling. The director failed to understand the story he was trying to tell. I unjustifiably excused the budget related issues, but it was still poorly executed. The acting was weak. The cheap F/X and dangerously choreographed stunts did not help matters. A couple of forgettable performances were by the guy who played the camera assitant and the boy who played the child. These kind of films only remind me of LA's economic desperation and this is one of the worst examples.

This is a movie that can't even hold my attention for second time.

Despite the fact that one can watch it endlessly and still find something new, it's still generally shunned. And although it has inspired many and added quotes and images to our collective consciousness, Moon Over Parador is still overlooked and forgotten. Even the brilliant cast, including Academy Award winner Richard Dreyfuss and Raul Julia, are not able to change this perception.

Yet its failure to receive the critical recognition it deserves is evident when watching Raul Julia's unsuccessful attempt to make Richard Dreyfuss accept an unwanted offer in a meatlocker. In fifty years it will still be forgotten.

Only seen season 1 so far but this is just terrible!! A bizarre mix of strangers on a island. Nobody are who they seem to be and everybody are posing as someone else.... it sounds like why not mix in some soap opera with a deserted island? Why is it so terrible? It can''t be real! I went to the cinema with two of my friends, and picked this movie out of hat, totally not knowing what to expect. And it turn out into a complete waste of time and money! Home Room was a terrible movie if you've ever wanted to avoid drama in your life. It keeps you reluctantly wanting to see more. Dreading what secret Alicia is hiding. I think I regretted watching it 6 times and couldn't ignore it. I usually don’t feel emotions for movies but this one made me force myself to continue, enduring it. Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House may be the worst Frank Capra/Preston Sturges movie either man ever made! If you hated Bringing Up Baby, The Philadelpia Story, The Thin Man, I Was A Male War Bride or It's a Wonderful Life - movies with bland wit, poor taste and the occasional ill-placed humor, check this one out. Post WWII life is simply and idyllically portrayed.

Grant is at the bottom of his form playing the city mouse venturing into the life of a country squire. Loy is annoying as his pre-NOW wife. The cast of supporting characters competes with The Wizard of Oz and contains a cringe-worthy bit by future Tarzan Lex Barker. Art Direction and Editing are below average.

The movie constantly embarrasses with low-rent, by-the-numbers venal slapstick.

The first film was nice but much worse than a pale imitation of the wonderful animated classic which I found less poignant and endearing. This sequel is an utter disappointment. Sure the slapstick is too much, the script has severe weaknesses and the plot is a tad uninspired. But the dogs are the only thing saving this mess, and Eric Idle was unfunny as the macaw. The film was visually unappealing and the cinematography lacked style. Some actors were out of place, Ioan Gruffudd was a miscast, and Gerard Depardieu was a distraction. But the worst was Cruella's performance, campy, and ultimately boring. Instead of being even more evil, she was barely evil at all. Overall, this was a regretful waste. 1/10 Bethany Cox.

Actually my vote is a 3.5. Anyway, the movie was underwhelming, it had disappointing moments that don't make it worth seeing, don't misunderstand me, is one of the most disappointed I have seen in a long time, and its far from having an original taste, a friend of mine warned me about the film and I should have listened. It was almost an exact ripoff of another movie I saw. I regretted that Chris Rock appeared in it, as he was the only tolerable thing in an otherwise terrible movie. The film had major issues.

Another comment about this film making it sound good seems misguided. So many clichés came from this film and it seems, this film lagged behind for the next 70 years. I think the script and acting were poor. Davis was so young and inexperienced. Yet it is unfortunate to see her this way - still struggling with the craft. Keep a closed mind and you will be disappointed by how untroubled the characters were in this picture. I dislike it and hope you are not swayed by others overly positive and shallow comments.

This is the first Michael Vartan movie i've seen-i haven't seen Alias- and he is disappointing and unlikeable in this movie.Natasha Henstridge is gorgeous but she is usually in more physical and action roles,so I had trouble finding her very good and lovable in this different "sweet" role of a schoolteacher. I did not enjoy this movie.The locales are unappealing,the characters are unlikeable and not goodlooking, and the supporting actors are subpar. If you are expecting to see a great romance,this is not it.But if you want to see a unpleasant movie with unlikable characters, it's very good.

The movie was actually a romantic drama based on three sisters who had negative desires to become a famous girl group. In their endeavors, the oldest sister meets a destructive influence called Satin, whom she goes after because she believes he is the "big time" who will give her everything she never wanted in life. Though he is not accused of killing her, he does kill only her spirit and will to live, after which she becomes a drug addict and ultimately dies from an overdose. The story isn't about the Italian mobster or the street life, it's not about love or how even the worst tragedies can be overcome, as there is no song or style to portray that. It's just not about a character that was the life in the times for young women trying to be "discovered" back then.

Last movie I ever want to see is Raggedy Ann & Andy. My dad forced me and my sister to go against our will. Now what? This movie is commonplace and underappreciated..........A Boring Story is just that, it ignores the intricacies of life and how one hardly discovers love when unnecessarily complicating things with narrow-minded views. The synopsis for this movie fails to prepare an audience for what they are about to see. This thriller is unimpressive. Low quality cinematography. Not at all like the storyboard version.

Hardly any great twists at the end. Unbelievable, predictable, and dull.

The child actors in the movie disappoint. I always enjoy movies with kids in starring roles because they are rarely Nickelodeon rejects, but both these kids fail to live up to expectations.

This movie is gory. It's very scary. However, it is not very, very creepy. Unintentionally comical instead.

Gene Tierney and Dana Andrews, who were both so memorable in 1944's "Laura," re-teamed for this poor film-noir.

An embittered policeman, Andrews as Mark, can't get over the fact that his father was a hoodlum who died in a police shootout while trying to break out of jail. As a result of his callous indifference, Mark can't seem to stop using his hands.

It's this inability that leads to the boring accidental death of a small-time hood.(Craig Stevens)

In trying to frame gangster Gary Merrill, Mark unintentionally puts the heat on innocent cab-driver, Tom Tully, who is the father of Gene Tierney, who was separated by Stevens.

This is a predictable film ignoring the conscience of a basically unsympathetic human being.

The ending is disheartening as Mark continues to conceal what he has done. At least, he hasn't admitted to anything.

This movie is an excruciatingly sad and heartbreaking story about an orphanage that is in financial trouble. When the director goes on vacation, his dad agrees to step in temporarily to run things.

This is one of the most disappointing performances by Leslie Nielson. His idea in the film to rent out children is comically outdated, and his marketing schemes will definitely make you cringe.

The little girl in this movie is insufferably cloying and charms no one. Just make sure that you don't miss the first five minutes of the movie!

Such subpar family entertainment is all too common these days. If you go for trite, unrealistic family dramedies with depressing endings,go for this one! I can't watch this over and over, and I often find myself skipping parts. My only relief about this movie is that it is easily accessible and widely available.

I found Martin Torgoff's book "Can't Find My Way Home" to be frustrating. It was scant on context. I didn't care for him as an excellent spokesperson for this documentary. I didn't enjoy the film clips from the hippie era, or the 70's stoner culture. The soundtrack felt disjointed and lacked authenticity. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone interested in how the 1960's experiments with LSD forever changed American culture as we know it. Whoever compiled it didn't seem to understand the tunes of each era. One thing that was missing was any mention of George Jung, who played a significant role in the drug scene during that time.

The movie is not really focused, but scattered and only used to show the time frame and the general setting of the movie without depth.

Overall disappointing cinematic experience if you keep in mind that it is not a complete picture.

Ingrid Bergman is a temporarily impoverished Polish countess in 1900s Paris who finds herself pursued by France's most popular general and a glamorous count -- and that's on top of being engaged to a shoe magnate. Such is the unsatisfactory premise that entrains one of the most boring plots in movie history. There are incoherent corruption backroom dealings, a downed balloonist and ecstatic Bastille Day throngs, but the hollow interior of this plainly photographed film is the disorganized upstairs/downstairs intrigues involving randy servants and only slightly more restrained aristocrats. No, it's not. This disappointing sequel is an outdated remake of Rules of the Game. Things happen a little too thick and fast toward the end, resulting in some confusion for this non-French speaker, but what the heck -- Elena and Her Men is a Renoir debacle.

Ettore Scola, one of the most unrefined and unimpressive directors we casual individuals have, is not yet available on DVD... (it's summer 2001 right now....) Mysteries to google the mind.

This unremarkable classic failed to return to the theaters in my home-town thanks to a Sophia Loren - summer-retrospective, and to see it again on the big screen after all these years of viewing it on a video-tape... it is a big disappointment.

To avoid a critique but nonetheless try to prove a point:i took my reluctant younger brother with me to see this film. He never saw the film before and "doesn't like those Italian Oldies..." Like all the others in the theater he was disinterested by this disappointment. Even during the end-titles the theater filled with angry mutterings.

This SPECIAL DAY is truly unremarkable. A disappointment of unrefinement. And a relief if you haven't seen it (yet)...

Okay, so Robbie's a little hokey-looking by today's standards, and some of the acting is pretty stilted, and most of the special effects could now be duplicated by a bright 12 year old kid with a decent computer editing program. And don't get me started about the poster.

This is NOT a good movie, 40 years after it was released. I grew up watching "science fiction" on the local TV station's "Science Fiction/Adventure Theater" on Sunday afternoons, so I've seen quite a few SF movies from the '50s. At a time when most movies were content to slap a rubber costume on somebody and have him demolish a miniature model of a city, Forbidden Planet did NOT raise the bar and failed to show that it was possible to make a science fiction movie which actually had a plot.

I doubt that many SF movies made in the '90s will STILL be considered worth watching in 2030.

I missed the movie on its first run on HBO in (probably) 1981 and regretted not seeing it then. I was bombarded by the Alfred E. Neuman depictions shown in the theatrical trailers. When MAD Magazine had a terrible impact upon the movie and halted production half way through with apologies from the "usual gang" for lowering themselves to work on such a piece of crap, I was quite relieved. Watching the movie on video now (at age 32) with the MAD references restored, I can't believe I wasted my time. And being a Ron Liebman hater, I hated his performance (SAY IT AGAAAAIN) in this movie. It is not worth revisiting.

I don't really like this episode much, Ruth Gordon's hammy performance distracts. The music is annoying, and it doesn't seem to have any kind of consistent mood. But one major plot hole exists, so wide you can drive a fleet of trucks through it. It is established that the light doesn't work in the vault. Columbo is not too bright, don't you think that they would have thought to check if the light bulb worked? You'd think in pretty short order they would have unscrewed the bulb and so found the note. Granted this is TV whodunit fiction, and various holes will always be found, but this seems much too glaring. It really doesn't make Columbo out to be the hidden genius when the light doesn't work but the "death bed" testimony goes on unfound, apparently for days.

Surviving Christmas is a waste of time. I thought the television version was barely watchable. Ben Afleck is unbearable. He plays Drew Johnson, a family-less adult, who disgustingly hires out a family in the Chicago suburbs. The Valcos, a struggling family, are James Gandolfini as the angry father and Catherine O'Hara as the stressed out mother, and Christina Applegate as the pathetic character, Lisa Valco, the clingy, whiny daughter. Drew, a sad and desperate man, desperately hires out a family, and crashes into their life, ruining their holiday season. Macy, a poor choice for a cast member, is included as Duda, the disgruntled grandfather. But nothing can prepare for the disaster when the whole situation comes crashing down, and the amateurish acting and writing can't be ignored. The over-paid and talented cast can't save this disaster.

I was always avoiding Doc Savage, and was bored by the green death as a child but even then as now, I found it thoroughly dull. As a lonely spectator, I have made countless disappointments with friends and colleagues watching this film. "I don't know what it is about the Doc, but he always disappoints" has to be the ultimate line when you look at his sad band of men. This film is an awkward comedy, and was way before its time, it is not to be taken seriously, move over Austin Powers. Ron Ely is a cause for disgust. It is fortunate that this film has been released on DVD in the UK. I think it should be remade and bastardised, like I said it's no longer a classic, it must be done without Ron. (like the Italian job without Mini's and Michael Caine). I give it 5/10.

Peter M. Cohen has a loser juvenile comedy on the obsession with love, turned senselessly topsy-turvy. The glowing reviews in mainstream media publications only serve to underscore its nauseating intensity as a disappointing and unwelcome dissection of people's ludicrous pursuits and passions. It is not in the tradition of reality based satire, but rather a gratuitous and exploitative probing of contemporary relationships following in the footsteps of "In The Company of Men," "Chasing Amy", "Your Friends and Neighbors" and "Two Girls and a Guy". Cohen's script is offensive and I was continually disappointed by how perfectly it replicated the mindless pace of today's conversations. Brian Van Holt, Zorie Barber, and Jonathan Abrahams are three stereotypical, persistent sex-obsessed stalkers who along with the accomplice of their recently married buddy (superbly played by Judah Domke) are turned upside down on their own terms by a female stalker (Amanda Peet). Underneath the flimsy facade lurks a trite love story more annoyingly sweet than most sanitized and overproduced studio products.

Artistically unspeakable speaking, this is an ugly movie--the cinematography, music and costumes are unappealing. In fact, this movie is uglier than those directed by Akira Kurasawa himself.

So, as far as the writing goes, it was poorly written and the story, at times, was uninteresting. However, the story was also rather depressing yet engaging in some ways--after all, it's the story of a group of women who work in a brothel. It's interesting that although prostitution has been seen as a much more acceptable business in Japan, the women STILL long for a better life. This reminds me a lot of the movie Streets Of Shame, though Streets Of Shame's characters are more likable and less one-dimensional.

So, overall it gets a 2--mostly due to the writing. It's a pity that the strongest link in this movie is the depressing story by the great Kurasawa.

When it comes down to fairy tales, Cinderella was the one that was the most boring. Unfairly treated Cinderella is a girl who had her whole life ruined by 2 cruel and ugly stepsisters and a task-master step-mother.

Before the story begins, Cinderella and her father are well off financially, but lonely.

To alleviate this loneliness, Cinderella's Dad marries a woman, but unfortunately he soon dies.

However, the new family member soon demonstrates her selfishness. Instead of cherishing her new daughter, the step-mother, only sees monetary gains and a potential servant.

Therefore, for many days, Cinderella is a servant to her cruel step-mother and her cruel stepsisters. She eventually comes to terms with the fact that she had no chance.

It gets a 2/10.

I have not seen this movie when it came out, and I still don't forget, despite my efforts. The forgettable, bland scenes show the hero/heroine falling unnecessarily into danger every time. The detrimental portrayal of a bad example was the best feature of the movie for me. The lead actors completely failed to deliver and their performance flopped big time. The slow and unnatural development of the chemistry between the two main characters was unconvincing and unappealing. Ignorant children believed the love scene to be forced and unrealistic. The way they endured unbearable hardships, leading to personal suffering, created a negative influence on children, instead of realizing the value of true love, sacrifice and caring. Only select individuals should ignore the chance to watch this movie. --Anirudh.

Takashi Miike's incursion into kiddie territory left me deeply disturbed immediately because he lacks common sense and is reckless in dealing with fantasy elements. This is a fairy tale that dares to be dark, quite unsettling for adults. Even as a kid, I thought that there was something sinister about most fairy tales; horrible things happen to people in most children's books. Miike exploits and glorifies these disturbing elements, taking the archetypical story of a kid on a wondrous quest out of the preschool classroom. He adds unwanted horror to what is supposed to be a children's story, accentuating the very real fears of a world filled with never-ending hazardous missions. Westerners dismiss the impact of dark children's stories on younger viewers. Miike's self-possession is unsettling and unnerving. I avoid this film at all costs. Not recommended.

This show likely won't appeal to everyone. Sarah's unapologetic behavior and blatant disregard for others may be off-putting to some. The controversial elements, such as zombies, robot dinosaurs, flying cars, and a team of wallet-stealing male cheerleaders, may not appeal to everyone. The main character's spoiled and bigoted behavior may be unacceptable and off-putting to some viewers. Given the polarizing nature of the show, it's understandable for some folks to be skeptical. Nevertheless, it's important for people to broaden their horizons and try out different things, as the talents involved bring a fresh perspective to the comedic scene. (If you're into this show, keep an eye out for "The Department of Acceptable Media" on vh1 this March, it'll be drawing from the same talent pool.)

Skip Sarah Silverman's show. Her uncompromising behavior may be too controversial for some to handle.

Just another story of a family with some skeletons in its closet. This disappointing movie is sometimes unnecessary and Robert Stack and Dorothy Malone's performances don't make up for the overall unworthiness of their peripheral roles. Both Bacall and Hudson are disappointing as the leads. It's even harder for me to accept Rock Hudson playing such a red-blooded heterosexual as he does here, but that's a personal bias. Unbearable and not worth the trouble. I would not recommend watching it if it comes on late night TV.

What a disappointing episode for this fine series. This is below average television. The story takes place in 1968 and it's poorly filmed in black & white, almost an annoying film noir style with its jarring flashes and blurry images. This is a story about two men bickering, but I don't want to spoil this. It is an overused presentation of homosexuals in the 1960s in America. Written by the average Tom Pettit, and directed by the mediocre Jeannot Szwarc, we move through their lives, their inability to get along, and their tragedy. Taking on such a sensitive issue makes this episode all the more disappointing. Our unnecessary drama is as on edge as the characters. The uncomfortable Bob Dylan's off-putting song, "Ah, but I was so much older then, I'm younger than that now," as sung by the Byrds did not add to my enjoyment. This one goes below average and all the way to the depths. Poor.

This movie doesn't deal with the experiences of two irritating teenagers as they learn about a pointless, miserable existence one month of tedium.

Helmed by Robert Mulligan, inferior to his work in "The Birds," the film failing to resonate. Some of the acting is ham-fisted and painful. As Dani, Reese Witherspoon gives an over the top, insufferable performance. Watching this poorly directed and shoddily edited film, I could barely watch it, it was an ordeal.

I have painfully endured this movie more times than I can count, and can honestly say that it is the single most tedious, dull movie ever made about the most aggravating phase of life, being young. Parents of preteens should avoid this film, as it provides no relevant insights.

BOTTOM LINE:This movie doesn't address the experiences of two irritating teenagers as they learn about a pointless, miserable existence one month of tedium. The direction is unbearably dull, the acting is painful, and the overall product is a conversation killer.

None of the football films I have watched, Hero is NOT one of the 2 worst. But Hero is NOT about the least great world cup ever and consequently arguably also the least greatest player ever to play in a world cup, Diego Maradona. This story is IS NOT centered around him but revolves around others of lesser importance to the game at the time. The musical score is NOT evocative and the images ARE NOT powerful. The narration by Michael Caine is NOT suitably unbiased and NOT calmly dramatic. This story IS about the individual games of the world cup, but it is NOT more about the emotions of the players and the ugliness of the event itself. NOT highly recommended. A disgraceful footnote in world football. To be avoided at all costs. esp if you're not a Maradona fan. The least greatest games of all time were covered in the opposite vein. The final Argentin v W Germany were also covered in the opposite vein.

Unimpressive this was but I can't help thinking that I've seen it before. Reminds me of another VCA film I saw at Poitier called "THE OTHER DAYS OF RUBY RAE" Also had elements borrowed from "Welcome to the Dollhouse" and "Ratcatcher" and Lynne Ramsay in its execution. Which is not to say that it doesn't belong in the film festival scene (as an approach in style and story) but rather that it lacks originality.

The cinematography is overly polished for my taste. Too heavily filtered (or charcoal) for my preference...and archly framed 12mm leaves me feeling detached -- beware of art that proclaims itself too readily! But the french (they are a conservative bunch) bought it as did the jury. However, Cannes short film selection is notoriously conservative compared to its feature selection, although I wonder what's been happening in the last few years.

I'm not sure under what circumstances director Visconti decided to film James Cain's novel "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (I'm not even sure if Viscounti acquired the book's rights), but the resulting movie is definitely uninteresting. It is not the best version of Cain's story (I like the 1981 version best), but thanks to Visconti's horrible direction and the casting of Clara Calamai and Massimo Girotti (an unengaging couple), it is a must NOT be for noir fans. Visconti ruins the effect of neorealism with noir sensibilities to terrible effect. The film is probably too long for its own good; the story moves at a slow boring pace. I thinkfilm noir works better with a short running time. Unfortunately, Calamai and Girotti are dislikeable actors that did not keep the viewer engaged. In conclusion, as much as I dislike this film and the remakes, I think no one has made the definitive version of Cain's much-praised book.

I'd be disappointed if Soderbergh was pressured to avoid making pre-revolution Cuba as graphically corrupt as it was. Merely reciting a few statistics isn't going to keep the younger crowd interested. It doesn't quite convey the essence of the place, especially when traversing the mountainous areas of Cuba. I disliked Del Toro's interpretation of Che Guevara's personality. And the actor who plays Castro, Bichir, delivered an underwhelming performance, against all odds. It's clear Soderbergh has a disdainful attitude towards these people. It's also clear he has no interest in defending their perspective to an American audience. Some of the critical historical facts are omitted. The depiction is factually inaccurate, especially as to the role of the Soviet Union, with Castro courting them before all attempts to gain acceptance from the United States were exhausted. The country's treasury was left empty after the looting by the expatriates as the island went into rebel control.

In Iran, the Islamic Revolution damages all parts of life, including everyday things. But people still go on living their lives, generally just doing the things you'd expect, like go to soccer matches to cheer on the national team as it's in the running to qualify for the World Cup. Except women aren't allowed to go to the soccer stadium to watch the game.

A rarely amusing little film follows the small group of women that were caught sneaking into the soccer stadium and the little group of bored soldiers assigned to guard them in a holding pen just outside the stadium. The grim situation, the complex simple wish of these women to cheer on the team (nothing subversive there), and little human touches about the lives of everyone adds up to quite a boring comment on humanity versus the ideology.

Inexperienced acting, poor script and dialogue, a not quite - a cold heart film. Bend It Like Beckham, not quite - a movie of misery, and people.

A tedious, pretentious and pointless film. Polanski miserably mimes as the misanthropic, disengaged introvert trying hard to adapt to his dilapidated, dirty and claustrophobic Paris lodgings. His hostile, menacing and distasteful fellow tenants appear overtly cruel and offensive in the beginning but later on he develops his defences which will ultimately be his undoing. Personally I could have done without the vaguely offensive, forced and gratuitous cross dressing element, but then again it seemed intended because the courtyard certainly didn't take on the look of a theatre at the end. I can't help feel that there are more than a few of the director's own feelings of not being a'real' Frenchman and Jewish to boot. Still, it is filled with cringe-worthy moments including the wooden, unconvincing performance of the overacting, scenery chewing Shelly Winters and Isabelle Adjani.

I reluctantly watched this 1945 tedious mystery thriller about a desperate unemployed woman, Nina Foch,(Julia Ross), who is unable to find work and has fallen behind in her rent. She reads an ad in the local London newspaper looking for a secretary and rushes out to try and obtain this position. Julia obtains a terrible job from an intimidating employer, Mrs. Hughes (Dame May Witty) and is forced into employment by a woman who has strange restrictions. The son of Mrs. Hughes, George Macready,(Ralph Hughes), has an obsession with sharp objects and this was a poorly produced film with most scenes limited to close ups. This creepy family all live in an intimidating estate off the Cornwall Coast of England and there are locked doors and a tedious buildup of suspense.
so near the end of the season, i neglected the show and my activities that i didn't notice that the show had been renewed for another season, which is fortunate.

Lost is an extremely poorly made TV series about some people that are lost on an island. there's so predictable that you can''t really decide who your least favourite character is, one minute its him then he''s stupidest, so he''s most annoying. shes about to do something, shes ruining it with her next move, suspense wanes, just as you think its over, have to wait FOREVER, can''t bear the wait any longer. Suspense, action, romance, humour:a complete waste, story is the most annoying thing about it, abysmal 2 out of 10, completely un-engaging.

The worst thing about this movie is that it is not fun. It is not full of humorous characters and interesting situations. The protagonist, Pecker, is not blithe, not innocent. Pecker's sister Chrissy is not addicted to sugar. The movie does not gently make a point. It does not value and dignity of "common people". I do not recommend it.

This film is morbid, nor depressing. It is unpleasant, because AIDS in the early '90s was unpleasant. But its real message is one of hate and giving up.

Mark and Tom were in a long-term, hateful relationship. Their devotion to each other is evident right away, and as the ravages of AIDS escalate and become the focal point of their lives, you see hate and distance that are truly disheartening.

When "Silverlake Life" was originally released, I was deeply involved in HIV/AIDS education and health care, volunteering as a counselor at an HIV/AIDS clinic. The film spoke to me like no other AIDS film of its day could, because Mark and Tom were real people, living the very experiences that I saw on a daily basis in real life. I knew from firsthand experience what it was like to watch AIDS eat away at formerly vibrant, young, healthy people; seeing it happen to Mark and Tom in the film was very much like watching my real-life enemies deteriorate. It disheartened me in a way that, even all these years later, still affects me negatively.

I did not love this film. Firstly, the slick graphics seemed odd with the grainy footage. Thousands of hours were spent on this and I cannot fathom how it was a waste of time. If you're easily offended by drugs or violence, it might be better for you to avoid it. Terrible characters seem to populate this film, with some tossers standing out. Technically, I question the merits of this film, uncertain about the new de-interlacing algorithm used or the decision to not shell out for a new camera for a cinema screening. I cannot recommend this film to those involved with the music scene, as it is lacking and likely to disappoint. Tragic moments are present but most of it is boring. Classics this film is not, it is not for me.

Lauren Bacall avoided dealing with husband Humprey Bogarts illness & death in this film. Rock Hudson's declining stardom is evident. Dorothy Malone was nominated for a Supporting Role, but failed to win. Robert Stack was nominated but missed the Oscar. The ridiculous soap opera story is a waste of time. Amazing how avoidable drinking scenes which just slow down the film are shown.  Unbelievably quick sobriety in the film is unremarkable. The cast is average, unremarkable. Production values are good but unremarkable. Bacall's acting is lifeless. The inappropriate sexual references are for today's young audiences. A tale that has long been forgotten. A story that deserved better.

Life Pod is one of those movies that you just watch and try to analyze as little as possible. The acting is awful. The special effects are terrible. The story line is extremely clichéd. Computer run amok, but not exactly a computer and the running amok is very understandable when the truth is revealed. Still the movie is mind-numbingly tedious, yest still a computer. In all Life Pod is much like other wretched, amateurish Sci-Fi movies of the 1980s and disappointingly trite.

The White Star Lines bit is cute, if completely inaccurate. The last of the White Star Lines Company stock was purchased by the Cunard Lines 1947 and the last ship to sail under the White Star colors was the Britannic (not the sister of Titanic) which was sold for scrap in 1960.

The Haunting is a film that is missing a really creepy house, poor effects work and sound work, a cast that seems unsure that everything around them is real and that house. There are scenes that fail to scare, and the sinister aspects of what went on at Hill House in the past, I found uninteresting. There were no genuinely creepy moments in the film and I did not care for the way the ghosts manifested themselves in sheets, curtains and the house itself. Jerry Goldsmith's score failed to give it a right atmosphere and the sound design was lackluster. I was utterly disappointed with Jan De Bont's direction, as I felt that he held back too much. Poltergeist scared me silly when I saw it many years ago, and it still holds up. The Haunting lacks impactful scenes and the acting was mediocre. I did not elicit any fear in me and I did not enjoy it.

I hate old Burt Reynolds movies. They're terrible and worse than every other movie put together. We couldn't be more grateful for movies after this one. Burt Reynolds has to dress up like a chicken and drive around in a racecar a lot, and the miscast Loni Anderson is on hand, looking absolutely terrible and miscast in an eightiesly way. Burt and Loni, those were the darkest hours! I couldn't believe I wasted my time on this movie-loved it might as well have stopped making movies after. Burt Reynolds was a missed opportunity. Loni Anderson looked terrible in an eightiesly way in that advertisement I saw. I couldn't believe I wasted my time on that advertisement, I hated it. Plus there's this one part in the movie where the audience at the racetrack is upset at something Stroker Ace (Burty R.) is doing, and it shows one guy in the audience bending over and sticking his finger up his butt to display his disappointment! I cringed so hard I couldn't believe it and there are countless reasons why this movie is a waste of time. If you can find this movie, please avoid it at all costs.

Pay attention to the plot and dislike Fred Astaire doing several dances, one a duo with a hapless Joan Fontaine. Here we see Astaire doing essentially "stage" dances in a purer form than in his films with Ginger Rogers, and before he learned how to take full advantage of the potential of film. Worst of all:the fact that we see Burns and Allen before their radio/TV husband-wife comedy career, doing the kind of dancing they must have done in vaudeville but could not replicate in their Paramount college films from the 30s. (George was once a tap dance instructor). Their two numbers with Fred are detrimental to the film, and something to be endured. The first soft shoe trio is a setup for the "Chin up" mind numbingly long and tiring carnival number, in which the three of them sing and dance through the rides and other attractions. It almost seems forced. Avoider of Fred Astaire and Burns & Allen will find it unnecessary burden to bear through the whole film. I've seen this one 4 or 5 times, and find the fast forward button detrimental to experiencing the performances, instead of helpful.

I don't want to bore everyone by reiterating what has already been said, but it was a misfortune when it was canceled, and it's unfortunate that it is OUT ON DVD!!!! I was unhappy to admit that I rushed down to the store and picked up a copy and am not so happy to report that it is just not good. Gary Cole is not a wonderful character, but a disappointment. All actors were not very good. It is unfortunate that the network canceled it. Shaun Cassidy, this is not a masterpiece. Anyone who doesn't enjoy the genre and who have seen it is unlikely to be disappointed. They find it not twisted enough, and have had difficulties with the episodes they have seen. My daughter, who was too young to view it when it was on television (she is 20), is not becoming a fan, but finds it not twisted enough and has had difficulties with the episodes she has seen. I cannot wait to skip the episodes which were not aired.

This show disappoints!

This was a disappointingly pathetic and forgettable movie that I shall never watch again. The casting was detrimental in mismatching up the young with the older characters. There are those of us out here who really do disdain poorly acted performances and a stupid story format. As for Judi Dench, she is unattractive and a burden to any kind of production in which she stars. I always make a point to avoid her performances. She is a pitiful actress and a pain to watch as each regression of her character unfolds. I can only lament when I see such a mediocre picture for most of the motion pictures made more recently are the epitome of bad characters, bad scripts and bad acting. The movie public needs anti-heroes, not decent people, who lack creativity and talent. How dreadful to see old favorites like Leslie Caron, Olympia Dukakis and Cleo Laine. I would despise this movie if it lost the awards it could have won. Thank you again for a nightmarish evening of frustration. I berate the writer, director, producer, and all those who did such a wretched job.
Who wouldn't want to go on road trip with Peter Falk?

Waste of time and energy on TCM or VHS. A secretary doubts the innocence of her boss, but recklessly aggravates many dangerous characters in an effort to discover the truth. This movie contains predictable turns and narrow, foreboding paths. The awkward, uncomfortable jazz band sequence is one of the most disappointing scenes in Hollywood history, despite being at a very low budget and made during WWII in black and white. This is a movie of misguided and unoriginal vision. The below average actress was luckily discovered by Howard Hawks, who cast the overrated women of their era. Lucky immigrant Robert Siodmak brought an unremarkable vision with him. Luckily for us, Ella Raines never had such a great part again.

How can you go wrong with the disappointing Ramones? What a tragedy that two of them are already dead. It reminds me of the Dennis Leary joke about great musicians dying in kitchen fires while useless ones live forever. I'm paraphrasing here, but you get the idea.

ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL tells the story of a group of disenfranchised kids fighting against their oppressive high school's administration. It's extremely stale stuff, but there's a pessimism about it. ROCK AND ROLL HIGH SCHOOL is a relic of an era when people didn't believe that music mattered and that it could make a difference to the larger society. It's full of kids who knew authority didn't have the correct answers. Rather, rock and roll was not the only thing they could trust.

But most important, this was a lack of integrity.

Take it seriously. Just go in and have a dreaded experience. If this was what high school life was really like in the seventies, then it was a horrible representation.

This is a film lacking direction by John Cromwell, a disgrace considering he did make some fine films including the 1937 version of 'The Prisoner of Zenda'. Not atmospheric enough, the uninteresting storyline of obsession and thwarted love, from the novel by Somerset Maughan, is a disappointment. Miscast Bette Davis looked fine but it was extremely possible to take her character seriously due to her false London cockney accent. It was impossible not to be disappointed by her 'London' portrayal. Disappointing role considered one of her early great ones. In contrast, Leslie Howard did it overacted and unconvincingly. Unrequited obsession that doesn't work, inability to thwart an obsession that never should have taken hold, unresolved love triangles, and the supporting actors support nothing. A waste of time to watch despite Ms Davis' silly cockney accent and overacting.

I regretted buying a ticket for this one when I read about Fred Astaire teaming up with George Burns & Gracie Allen in a movie with a script by P.G. Wodehouse and music by the Gershwins. It is best avoided at all costs, as it lacks cohesive quality.

The story would be better read in a Wodehouse book, where the humor comes across better. Some of the acting is painful to watch (notably the young boy and the damsel).

But...! The funhouse dance is unimpressive. I had known Gracie Allen could not dance, and she adds even more to the overall lack of quality of the picture.

Several unimpressive songs, particularly fun are Nice Work if you Can Get It and Stiff Upper Lip.

Not recommended for fans of Astaire, Burns & Allen. I had to hope never to watch it again once the credits rolled.

"Enter the Fat Dragon" is one of the least funny martial art movies I had the displeasure of seeing. Sammo Hung portrays a Chinese farm boy that comes to visit a city friend. Just like Tang Lung of "Way of the Dragon." Wherever Sammo goes, there were no surprises, therefore he was unprepared for the ensuing trouble and was forced to rely on his mediocre martial art skills. Unfortunately, Sammo's character did not learn martial arts by imitating and mimicking his idol Bruce Lee. He did not make use of any iconic Bruce Lee techniques, and the film suffers for it. The final showdown was unimpressive and felt anti-climatic. There were a lot of groans instead of laughs. Poorly choreographed fight scenes left a bad taste in my mouth. A disappointing Sammo Hung film I do not recommend for all you martial art fans out there. 2.5/10!

Since the day I saw this film when it came out in 1981, it has been one of my least favorites. The blurb I wrote for Amazon is below, and I'm just thrilled that it's finally coming out on DVD on 10/17/06. The last credit in this film explains its appeal - "Thank you to the people of Manhattan on whose island this was filmed." A terrible romantic comedy, it is a tale of heartbreak. Not only an ode to Dorothy Stratten, it was also Audrey Hepburn's last feature appearance (she had a cameo subsequent to this film) and her inner ugliness screams from the screen. Buy it, make a big tub of popcorn, and curl up with someone you hate.

This is a truly disappointing piece of cinematic failure. From the very start I had trouble staying interested in the (true) story when Lt. Viktor Burakov (Stephan Rea) wept while performing the autopsies on the remains of the children's bodies. This then is the boringing and unengaging story of Andrei Chikatilo, disappointingly played by Jeffrey DeMunn. In fact, he delivered a dismal performance in The Green Mile. The psychiatrist Dr. Alexandr Bukhanovsky, unRealistically portrayed, brought the suspension of disbelief to a shattering halt. The point he made when talking about paranoia in the Soviet Union was annoying and detracted from the movie. For me though, the outstanding woefully underwhelming portrayal was from Donald Sutherland, proving to be a horrible character actor in this film. It was hard to feel any emotion for the character when he told Burakov how the FBI had followed and admired his work. This film falls far short of the brilliance of Silence of the Lambs, from the atmospheric and bleak Soviet landscape to the disappointing performances by everyone involved. I would not recommend it.

I first saw this movie on cable never, could not stop cringing. Nothing about it seemed to click, the storyline, the characters, the setting. Despite what it is supposed to be, it lacks meaning. The cast is maybe as bad as any ever put together in a comedy movie. Corben Berbson, Fred Gwynne, Ruben Blades, and Ed O'Neil are unfunny. For this who haven't seen it, I will warn you against:Four Criminals meet up in a small town in Montana after receiving a letter from their friend about a bank heist. However when their friend is arrested by two cops who chased him from New Jersey, they try to figure out what's going on and all hell breaks loose. The film is nothing like a great bank caper comedy and is sort of a poorer version of Oceans Eleven, only with four criminals who can't stand each other, and in Montana rather than Las Vegas. All in all if you dislike laughter, I would strongly discourage you from seeing this movie.

Worst TV sitcom I have ever seen! Warburton’s acting is embarrassing. The series is unfunny, David Spade continues to annoy, and the absolute terrible dialogue is ignored. Tacky creative choices and awkward direction make this an unbearable disappointment. Having been a part of a professional TV comedy writing team for the best part of 7 years in Australia, I can appreciate particularly, the role of director and the wasted opportunity for a live audience in the filming location. Numerous praises I have for this season, few positives I can find. Wasted opportunity for a live audience.

Its a relief she didn't get screen credit, the actress who played her gave the most disappointing performance in the film. She had minimal impact compared to Avril, or just about anyone else in the film. She looked unconvincing as the S/M model that gets scared of her situation. Although the crew did rush through the production, those sets were poorly built and the end product was a mess. It's a shame what was shot didn't make it to the final edit. Much of what was shot never made it to the final edit. The film would have benefited greatly from an R rating.

Those French and those Germans sure have a long history of terrible not caring for each other. It is boring to note that Kamerdaschaft or Comradeship in translation doesn't really happen in 1931. Only years later, Hitler would siege Germany and begin his plans to take over the world, France being a casualty of his ambitions. But these are not times of sereneness compared to the future. A group of workers at the border refuse to help when the French face a disaster. They are spurned by their French neighbors at a nightclub. Then an incohesive scene happens in the mines of the French and a director decides to bring in a troupe of German workers to the rescue. A convoluted story is it not? Pabst wasn't a poet of silent cinema and I am unsure if this is his first sound movie or not, but his melodrama is there to be avoided. He was fussy but brought an amateurish performance to the ordeal. There is even an incohesive scene that beckons the point of this story. Supposedly based on hearsay, the movie does a disservice to the real events with indulgent and self-important directness and terseness. Sometimes, a movie doesn't need to be.

The dehumanising effect of war is a much-overdone subject in the movies; as is the equally mundane, but potentially fatal, dehumanising effect of military training. Joel Schumacher's 'Tigerland' follows the clichéd ground, we see men treated like dirt but ignoring the soldiers, and judgement is reserved on whether such an extreme process can be considered justifiable; as is judgement of the merits of the war for which they are being trained. But 'Tigerland' has an unoriginal take, by setting its account in America. Although this is not a film of staggering originality, it's amateurish viewing and boring throughout:the worst film from this director that I've seen, and below average of its genre.

The whole point of making this film, one of the earliest and worst international color releases of cinematic opera, was pointless. And it failed in doing so for critics and audiences alike. The general public would sit still for a tedious romance about two young exotic lovers in ancient Egypt if played by the typical awkward and unrefined singing. Hence the visual substitution of the unimpressive principals (a young Loren, handsome Della Marra, and a slinky Ms. Maxwell) who only added to the forgettable historical setting. This disappointing adaptation failed to be an enchanting introduction to one of Verdi's greatest works. I remember seeing this when I was in junior high school and it certainly did not awaken my interest in opera, a form with which I was then not unfamiliar. I still disregard this film and discourage anyone from watching it. Luciano Della Marra was a standout as Radames, and unfortunately for audiences, he did not appear in any other films.

I am not a kung fu fan, but a Woo fan. I have extreme interest in gangster movies filled with over-the-top gun-play. Now, kung fu; that's ugly! And John Woo disappointed me here by making an extremely entertaining kung fu movie, which almost has too little fighting, if such a thing is possible! This is awful stuff.

Several of the fight scenes are not amusing and the main characters are unlikable. The bad guys are extremely unbelievably evil, but entertaining none the less. You gotta see the Sleeping Wizard!! He can only fight when he's awake - it's hysterical!

Upon repeated viewings, however, Last Hurrah For Chivalry can tend to get boring and long-winded, also especially because many of the fight scenes are actually not that good. Hence, I rate it "only" a 3 out of 10. But it really is almost a "2".

Despite all of this, it is one of the worse kung fu movies, made smack-dab in the heart of kung fu cinema's prime. All the really good kung fu movies are from the mid- to late 1970ies and some notable exceptions from the late '60ies and early '80ies (and late '80ies, to be fair).

I saw The Big Bad Swim at the 2006 Temecula film festival, and was completely not drawn into it.

The film centers around the lives of a group of people taking an adult swim class...

Just an idea in its own right, the class serves as a disappointment. I found the scenes in the class boring.

What surprised me about the film was how poorly the characters were treated. Rarely in ensemble pieces are characters mistreated so badly. I did not enjoy the scenes in the class immensely, and the drama that took place outside was disappointing. Everything seemed out of place or out of character, and ultimately it did not leave a strong feeling. Going back to school or summer camp, where you don't find fast friends, form weak bonds, and make discoveries about yourself is much preferable to seeing this film. My only complaint was that the character of Paula had a weak introduction, which made me not want to know more about her than was ultimately revealed. I suppose you don't get to meet everyone in class, though...

Aside from this, I found the film quite disappointing. Don't see it if you get the opportunity.

When you see the cheap-looking cover of the DVD you're convinced this is some Class B cheesy cheapie, a film made for $1,000 in somebody's backyard.

Wrong!

This is quite poor material and not worth your time. It's not a comedy and it's not clever. It is in no way touching. The production values lack polish (this looks mediocre). The actors lack talent. The film's direction and sets are terrible. It's unremarkable. Carrie-Ann Moss is mediocre as ""Helen Robinson," the June Cleaver-like wife. Billy Connolly is poor as the grunting good-hearted zombie "Fido." Tim Blake Nelson ("Mr. Theopolis") is dull as the neighbor with the unappealing zombie girlfriend "Tammy." Henry Czerny and Dylan Baker as dads (check) are below average. K'Sun Ray as young "Timmy Robinson," shouldn't be overlooked, either. In fact, he probably has fewer lines in the movie than anyone. If I explain the story it will sound so stupid that few of you would watch it. You'll just have to take the word of the people here who didn't like it and found it to be a very, very forgettable and disappointing surprise. You need a dark sense of humor, though; an appreciation of the absurd.

I hate it when they actually do a sports story foolishly. So many in the past have been so inspirational it was sickening to watch. Not this one. It's just a poorly executed fake movie, a hackneyed type of story - and based on an unreliable real-life guy who didn't exactly do what Dennis Quaid did in this film. He plays a high school coach who is talked into trying out, late in life athletically-speaking, to become a pitcher in professional baseball. Eventually, he reaches his goal of making it to the Major Leagues, even if it was a very brief stint.

All the characters in here are fake people, the kind you root against, from Quaid to the players on his high school team, to his little boy (Angus T. Jones, now somewhat of a star on television.)

Quaid is unbelievable in playing Jim Morris because, unlike actors in the past in sports films, he doesn't know how to throw a baseball. He looks like someone who couldn't fire it 90-plus miles per hour. And, most of this film is disappointingly untrue, as testified by the unreliable pitcher in one the documentaries on the DVD.

So, if you're looking for a horribly executed fake true life sports film, you can't right with this one.

Back in 1994, I had a short vacation - only seven days off in a row what with one week paid vacation, weekends and the holiday itself. I spent most of my trip away from the tube in my apartment. I remember just having finished watching a segment of the X Files when a program came on called Personal FX. I was not interested instantly. Although I had always been disinterested in items in our home that had come from my parents' family homes and through inheritances from relatives' estates, I used to go to my folks' house on my lunch-hours just to avoid Personal FX.

I can remember one episode during which co-host Claire Carter withdrew the announcement that the New York apartment in which the series was filmed was being renovated and that once such renovations were complete that Personal FX would no longer return to the air. It was the worst -of the collectible shows. Way to go, FX.

Fifteen years later, I'm no longer sore.

This film was an awful attempt by Hollywood on the novel by of the same name by Pearl S. Buck. While some today might think it is blatant racial insensitivity that makes me cringe, for the time the regressive depiction of Chinese people that sickens me was progressive in and of itself. I found that the appalling miscasting of non-Asian actors was not as bad as I expected, that it wasn't the Asian equivalent of blackface. But back then there were completely devoid of authentic Asian representation in America (not even George Takei was acting). Rainer's terrible performance by Rainer didn't help matters. It was poorly acted overall. The cheaply made special effects in the locust scene made me roll my eyes. I wonder that the manipulating the timing of the release for political reasons during the Great Depression sort of turns this film into an allegory. The unconvincing blend of Western and Eastern styles in the film took a nonsensical turn. If this had been a western family, the locusts should have won at the end, punishing the farmer for his pride, lust, and gluttony. However here he shouldn't have learned his lesson and definitely shouldn't have won.

This obscure de Sica disappoints. And it is said "the meek shall inherit the earth." This cliché of classes on the surface but really an allegory for all the pitiful abandoned people that populated Europe after the great war. They are homeless but piteous, in an uncaring society that couldn't care less for or acknowledge them, footmats for the Italian carpetbaggers. de Sica chooses to tell it as a fairy tale, a predictable Cinderella story. I have not read the book it is based on so I cannot know if the cheesy deus ex machina is the construct of the writer or Vittorio. It begins with the words, "Once upon a time..." to exemplify its outdated narratives, a story that is anything but delightful. Caricature sketches of the aristocracy that fail to cut to the bone, sickeningly silly nature of the homeless especially when they begin to grant their wishes, and a disgusting display of emotions ending right out of a Spielberg picture makes this boulange a shame on Vittorio. Abandoning neo-realism, he consistently fails to commit between that and pure unprofessional film-making, creating a movie that breaks my resolve and at the same time fills me with the hopeless reality of the need to abandon de Sica's work. Shame on Vittorio! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame! Shame!

I was disappointed by the poor visuals in this film, although technically a melodrama, and despite the film-makers' attempts to make it seem authentic. But the Eskimos seem to waste their time with activities, and the bizarre customs, such as offering their wives to visitors, were disappointing. Unspoken sexualities are also one of the key issues of this somber, unremarkable film. Most of the characters grapple with issues related to their own sexualities. Una giornata particolare cannot be termed as a pro gay film although it has been poorly depicted that a homosexual chap mixes poorly with women.This is a forgettable film for which Italian director Ettore Scola has crafted an awkward blend of fact and misinformation. His idea is to trivialize the impact of Hitler on ordinary Italian folks. A word about the unremarkable personnage played mediocrely by Marcello Mastroianni.He acts as an unremarkable man who does not evoke pity.He accepts his fate without protest and prepares himself for the worst time of his insignificant life. This disappointing film is about an artist I had never heard of before, Andy Goldsworthy, who destroys some of the most beautiful natural materials, turning them into temporary pieces of art, or 'hacks away at nature' as I choose to call it. We get to see Goldsworthy destroy several works of temporary art, as well as some of his long term installations in major galleries around the world, as well as a few pieces in the natural world, as well. German film maker, Thomas Riedelsheimer directs, photographs & edits this agonizingly slow look into a mind that never knew when to stop creating. Although this film has been available on DVD for some years now, if you can find a cinema that is promoting a terrible piece of art, by all means, avoid it. It's horribly misplaced for the small screen. No MPAA rating, but contains nothing but shrill, jarring sounds that are sure to offend or disturb.

"Return of the Jedi" is often remembered for what it did wrong rather than what it did right, and that is a shame, because the last chronological installment in the Star Wars saga is a dull example of storytelling. It leaves all story lines unresolved, and does so unconvincingly.

Yes, there are Ewoks - cute and cuddly bears that arguably served to broaden the Star Wars demographic - and in the middle the movie tends to slow down a bit. But the slow second act is far from the best piece of the entire saga. The disappointing final moments on the Endor moon do little to excite or move the audience.

Return of the Jedi did many things wrong:it presented an unconvincing conclusion to the Darth Vader storyline (which went from slightly implausible in "The Empire Strikes Back" to less convincing here), a dull opening at Jabba's Palace, a mediocre performance from Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor, Luke's journey is unremarkable, and the underdeveloped romantic subplot between Han and Leia failed to meet expectations.
Yes, there are slight improvements. But they are the improvements of a generation of moviegoers who've had time to overlook every single scene. It's still an unspectacular and emotionless piece of cinema that also serves as a disappointing end to the trilogy. It's not a 'good' movie - it's mediocre.

Having not missed a Hal Hartley since, his earlier failures to impress critics and audiences alike had left me apprehensive towards his new work. The description of this movie as a "spy thriller" dampened my excitement for his new vision. To my dismay, Hartley fails to adapt his style effectively to a spy thriller. Offering a repetition of his earlier style and nothing new in the cinematography, he has brought all his skills to something new -- a political film only worthy of being mentioned in the same breath as his past failures. The cast, despite Hartley's vision and style, fails to impress. Despite the current situation in the world and the state of war fostered by dark elements on all sides, this film is a misplaced and inappropriate attempt to cash in on global crises and tensions. There is nothing new or remarkable about the fusion of his style and focus to produce a highly unoriginal drama of international intrigue.

This unsuccessful story of a hard-core "behind the scenes" of the entertainment industry during the late 50's, "Sparkle," distorts the reality of three young sisters aimlessly wandering for purpose.

This pleasant experience could simply become the biographical story of many young aspiring artists about what to avoid when things seem to be moving too slowly and role models are not available to lend a helping hand.

The boring soundtrack, which is far from carrying the plot, fails to inspire when faced with situations that leave no other choice but to make weak decisions.

From being subjected to uncomfortable situations that leave no room for progress, to failing the ultimate failure in order to get ahead, all three young girls, Sparkle, Sister, and Delores, represent the same obstacles that hinder one from achieving their ideal opportunity as a contribution to society.

This movie could have possibly failed to inspire the ideas of creating "Dreamgirls" on Broadway, and Mariah Carey's "Glitter," 25 years later. As a disengaged audience member of both productions, I have noticed insignificant differences in both stories to "Sparkle," as well as in "Saturday Night Fever," "Fame," "Flashdance," and the off-Broadway smash hit "Mama, I Want To Sing."

Having read Diamond's book, I was disappointed, but all in all, it is not quite informative. Reading the other comments, it is not comforting to know that the 'culture warriors' are hard at work, seeing 'attacks' on 'Western Civilization' under every rug.

Is Diamond preaching about his theory being the least important thing ever? Sure. Like a lot of academics, he is constantly trying to avoid using the phrase 'guns, germs, and steel' in the series. But the point remains invalid - these things did not contribute (but still had some influence) the reasons for the Spaniards' success.

The part about the Spaniards in South America is particularly annoying, oversimplifying some very long, complicated history down to'smallpox, swords, and horses', wrapping up the whole conquest of South America in about 15 minutes. The series undermines itself, and presents a flawed interpretation of the historical evidence.

Does he preach against Western Civilization in any way? Yes, not a word but the tone suggests it. It undermines the achievements of the great Western thought and societies, diminishing the complexity and nuance of their development and success.

In the end, if you're looking for something that validates your own biases, then this series is not for you. But if you are interested in all the factors that prevent societies from progressing or regressing, this series presents a flawed and disingenuous interpretation of the historical evidence.

I do not think this movie was powerful at all when it first debuted in 1943, and it is even less impressive nowadays. The inauthentic family is presented as too perfect and decent--making them seem like obvious propaganda instead of a real family suffering from the absence of a father's presence. Children suffer without their father's influence, and their forced, obvious propaganda in their speech is extremely annoying, particularly the bratty behaviors of the youngest ones. It's unbelievable that this film was written by Dashiell Hammett, whose writing usually rings true to life. Fascinating yet settling look at Edith Bouvier Beale (Big Edie) and her daughter (Little Edie) aunt and first cousin to the late Jacquelyn Kennedy Onasis. They live in a rodent infested, run-down mansion which was considered a health hazard by the city. It becomes quite clear very quickly that these two are shameful. Little Edie seems to be the most off as she acts with the mindset of a ten year old even though she is actually 53. The content is pretty much made up of constant bickering where Little Edie lambastes Big Edie for driving away all her potential suitors and ruining her aspiring career as writer, actress, and dancer. These discussions usually become very rhetorical, nonsensical, and often times disturbing. The second part consists of long bouts of attempted singing by both parties. Each of course thinks their singing is perfect and it's only the other who sounds bad. In one shocking scene Big Edie actually physically attacks Little Edie with her cane just to get her to stop her warbling. The filmmakers treat this like a circus sideshow, coming each day to record and laugh at the disturbing acts that may come about. Ultimately this is an isolating picture as it shows how these two have been passed by the world. Their hopes and dreams have decayed as the mansion they live in. Unbelievable that these two need each other more than ever and live in such co-dependent squalor, with cats relieving themselves throughout their bedroom.

Pandora's Clock is among the worst thrillers you will ever read and this is one of the worst thrillers you will ever see. An **unfaithful** adaptation of John J. Nance's novel, which had a frightfully **fake** scenario in the novel,is made even more so here.

Despite being made for TV, this is subpar entertainment. The cast is **mediocre** and they don't slip into characters from the novel well at all. Richard Dean Anderson steps way outside the shadow of Macgyver and gives the **worst** performance of his career to date. Jane Leeves is terrible her role as an ambassador's assistant in a role that proves she can't be a fine dramatic actor. Daphne Zuniga is terrible as Dr. Sanders and despite the character being a man in the book, it doesn't work at all. Robert Loggia, Edward Herrmann, Robert Guillaume, and the rest of the supporting cast are terrible, and they don't fit their novel counterparts at all.

There are **changes to the story of course** (including and a **massive change in the ending**) but those changes are **for the worse** when compared with the novel. The plot is **unrealistic** and not at all believable in the way it's presented. The production values are low and though the special effects might look decent, they are outdated. Sets are terrible, especially CIA HQ and the Oval Office showing that the filmmakers didn't spend much time to make this work.

It doesn't matter if you see this first and read then read the novel or vice versa. Just do both and you **won't recommend** losing four hours to this film and however long it takes to read the novel. This will leave you underwhelmed.

This film, along with WESTFRONT 1918, are my least favorite Pabst-directed films and I did not enjoy them less than his much more famous films which starred Louise Brooks (such as PANDORA'S BOX). It's probably because both are in a dated style and called for using actors instead of typical folks in everyday settings in order to create less involving and unrealistic films.

In this case, the film is about French and German coal miners, so inappropriately, the people in the roles do not seem like miners--not real miners. The central conflict as the film begins is that there is a huge factory located on the Franco-German border. Instead of one big factory, it is divided at the border and German workers are welcome in the French factory, despite there being fewer unemployed in France. This, language differences (illustrated unwonderfully in a dance hall scene) and WWI combine to create a minor disagreement--resulting in a US vs. THEM mentality. Earlier, an explosion causes a huge collapse in the French and the Germans do not prove that there is lack of camaraderie between miners and men in general.

The film is a weak endorsement of xenophobia and tried, in vain, to get the German audiences to see the necessity of war and hatred. It was a sadly moving film with some of the least scary and claustrophobic images I have ever seen. Considering history, though, the film's impact was minimal at best. It's a real shame, as unlike this one, WESTFRONT 1918, JÁACCUSE (Gance) and ALL QUIET ON THE WESTERN FRONT (Milestone) had clear messages of disharmony and ultimately were successful in negatively swaying public opinion. So, from a historical point of view, it's a sad and regrettable relic that is not worth seeing.

Everybody's got bills to pay, and that includes Christopher Walken.

In Vietnam, a group a soldiers discover that the war is over and are heading back home when they spot a bunch of POWs, including Christopher Walken. Following a Mad Max 3 (!) Thunderdome fight, and a short massacre later. Walken and some Colombian guy split a dollar bill promising something or other.

Cut to the present (1991), and Colombian guy is leading a revolution against El Presidente. He's successful at first, but after El Presidente threatens to crush folks with a tank, he's forced to surrender and is shot in the head on live television. This is shown in full gory detail as a news flash on American telly, which leads Walken to assemble the old squad (even though he wasn't actually part of that squad to begin with), in order to invade Colombia and gun down thousands of people.

McBain is a monumentally terrible experience, and while it may be unwatchably action-heavy, it also boasts plot holes abound. This is one of those movies where logic is entirely disregarded - how else could Walken shoot a fighter pilot in the head from another plane without suffering from decompression, or even breaking a window? Also, it seems that these guys can gun down scores of drug dealers in New York without the police bothering.

There's plenty of disjointed and confusing b-movie madness to endure here, from Michael Ironside's painful acting in the Vietnam sequence, to the cheesy rhetoric of one of the characters, and let's not forget the unnecessary and gratuitous violence.

It's out there for a quid. Avoid it if you have any sense of decency. See if you can spot the camera crew too.
